results.title: Unreserved : stories from Truganina Explosives Reserve
results.brief_description:
Unreserved : Stories from Truganina Explosives Reserve is the culmination of a community arts project involving local residents and some of Melbourne’s up and coming designers. Based on oral histories collected from local residents who have a connection with this historic site, a series of animations have been produced recreating some of the unique stories of this site.
Truganina Explosives Reserve, one of Altona’s last intact historic sites, is located 26 kilometres west of the city, and nine kilometres from Williamstown on the shores of Port Phillip Bay. The reserve was established by the State Government in 1901 for the storage and handling of commercial explosives. After its closure in 1962, the reserve lay dormant for more than 25 years, protected from the outside world by the two and a half metre high galvanised fence.
In the 1990s, the reserve became the site of an intense community battle aimed at saving the site from redevelopment. The community embarked on a quest to save one of the western suburbs’ most significant historical and environmental locations, the site of an important early Australian industry.

results.title: ACMI in the regions: Stories from Moyne
results.creator_credit: David Withers, Roberto Salvatore, ACMI Content Development, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nine stories that embrace the spirit of three towns in the Moyne region in Victoria. Through interviews with the locals and footage of the region and various events, this compilation encapsulates life in Victorian towns today, the reasons for choosing the rural life over the city, activities, concerns and the things that bind these small communities together. Filmed as part of ‘ACMI in the regions’.

results.title: Pitcha this : memories of Fitzroy : Foundation for Young Australians : Digital Storytelling project
results.creator_credit: Arika Waulu, Deborah Deacon, Frances Gallagher, Howard Edwards, Kelvin Onus-King, Marlene Scerri, May Andy, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Seven Indigenous leaders in the community tell of growing up in Fitzroy. From disperate backgrounds, they have all become heavily involved with the activism and community spirit of Fitzroy in Melbourne, to grow into inspirational leaders for generations to come. Here they share their experiences and passions, as well as the families and communities they love.

results.title: Tim Burton official opening : Tim Burton : the exhibition
results.brief_description: This film highlights the excitement and celebration of the official opening of ‘Tim Burton: the exhibition’. A night filled with colour and sound. Amongst the fire eaters, stilt walkers and burlesque performers were the Tim Burton fans waiting to get a glimpse of their idol. The festivities start with the red carpet for VIPs that ran along the Flinders Street entrance and eventually inside ACMI’s Lightwell the official opening speeches were delivered.

results.title: Screen Worlds opening : September 2009
results.brief_description:
On Thursday September 17, 2009 ACMI’s new permanent screen culture exhibition Screen Worlds, was officially launched. The red carpet, VIP event attracted world wide attention with the attendance of both internationally recognised and home grown guests and artists. Kicking off the formalities was ACMI’s Board President, John Thwaites, followed by ACMI Director Tony Sweeney, Oscar® Winning Actress Cate Blanchett, Victorian Arts Minister Lynne Kosky and Victorian Premier John Brumby.
Following this, the ribbon is cut and guests enter the exhibition for the first time.

results.title: Len Lye: interview with Tyler Cann
results.brief_description: Tyler Cann, Curator of the Len Lye Collection at the Govett-Brewster Art Gallery in New Plymouth, New Zealand, visited ACMI during the Len Lye exhibition. Tyler Cann spoke about Len Lye’s influential and enduring body of work noting that this retrospective at ACMI is the largest and most comprehensive exhibition of the artist’s work to date. He focuses on particular works, some of which were reconstructed specifically for the ACMI exhibition.
